cfswitch.cfcase: Click the button on the right to update
Click arrow on left to return without submitting changes

Specify client IP addresses that should be allowed to invoke exposed services. This can be individual IP addresses, IP address ranges of the form 10-30, or * wild cards. Both IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are supported. To include an IP address in the list, enter the address and click Add. To delete an IP address from the list, select the address and click Remove Selected. When no IP addresses are selected, no user can invoke exposed services
Select Allowed IP Addresses for Exposed Services
View / Remove Selected IP Addresses for Exposed Services

You should restrict access to the ColdFusion Administrator to trusted users. By default the ColdFusion Administrator requires authentication to access these pages. However, if you configure your web server to restrict access to these pages, you can disable this authentication and rely on your web server's security instead. (Consult your web server documentation for details on securing pages.)
Select the type of Administrator authentication:
Separate user name and password authentication (allows multiple users)
To change the ColdFusion Administrator password for the root administrative user, enter a new password and confirm it below:
To specify a new seed value to encrypt data source passwords

The ColdFusion RDS service allows you to connect to this server using the RDS Password you define below. This is intended for development use only. If this is a production machine please check the checkbox to disable RDS.
You should restrict access to RDS to trusted users. By default RDS requires authentication. However, you may disable this authentication and rely on your web server's security instead.
Select the type of RDS authentication:
Separate user name and password authentication (allows multiple users)
To change the single RDS password, enter a new password and confirm it below:
Are you sure you want to delete this security sandbox?

ColdFusion's sandbox security uses the location of your ColdFusion pages to control access to ColdFusion resources. A sandbox is a designated area (files or directories) of your site to which you apply security restrictions. By default, a subdirectory (or child directory) inherits the sandbox settings of the directory one level above it (the parent directory). If you define sandbox settings for a subdirectory, you override the sandbox settings inherited from the parent directory.
Note: You can configure these settings prior to enabling them on the server. Also, you must restart the ColdFusion application server to enable this setting.

To use sandbox security in the multiserver and J2EE editions, the application server must be running a security manager (java.lang.SecurityManager) and you must define the JVM arguments, as describe in the Configuring and Administering ColdFusion manual and in the ColdFusion Administrator online Help.
To disable Sandbox Security, see the JRun section of the release notes.
To enable Sandbox Security, see the JRun section of the release notes.
To diable Sandbox Security, see the Sun ONE section of the release notes.

To disable Sandbox Security, see the Oracle section of the release notes.
To enable Sandbox Security, see the Oracle section of the release notes.
To disable Sandbox Security, see the BEA WebLogic section of the release notes.
To enable Sandbox Security, see the BEA WebLogic section of the release notes.
New sandbox, or pick one to copy from

Security Settings let users enable and disable access to ColdFusion tags, functions, and enterprise resources like data sources.
Note: You must restart ColdFusion to enable this setting.

To change your ColdFusion Administrator password, enter a new password and confirm it below:
Select ColdFusion functions that you want to disable. ColdFusion pages in this sandbox cannot use functions that are listed in the Disabled Functions box.
Select the ColdFusion tags that you want to disable. ColdFusion pages in this sandbox cannot use tags that are listed in the Disabled Tags box.

Select the data sources that can be used by ColdFusion pages in this directory. To select more than one data source, hold down the Control key and click the name of the data source. ColdFusion pages in the directory cannot use data sources listed in the Disabled Data Sources box.
Please note: The ALL DATASOURCES option includes all data sources not otherwise specified as enabled or disabled as well as all future data sources created in the Data Sources section of the ColdFusion administrator.
Add / Edit Secured Files and Directories:
Enter files that you would like to grant access for templates operations under this directory.

A file permission consists of a pathname and a set of actions valid for that pathname. A pathname is the pathname of the file or directory granted the specified actions. A pathname that ends in "/*" indicates all the files and directories contained in that directory. A pathname that ends with "/-" indicates (recursively) all files and subdirectories contained in that directory. A pathname consisting of the special token "<<ALL FILES>>" matches any file.
Are you sure you want to delete this server?
All ip:ports are open. There are currently no restrictions.
These settings restrict the IP addresses and ports that ColdFusion can access with the tags that call third-party resources; for example, the cfmail, cfpop, cfldap, and cfhttp tags.

To disable the Runtime Permissions for a ColdFusion page in this directory, select the Runtime Permission from the Enable Runtime Permissions box and move it to the Disabled Runtime Permissions box. To disable more than one Runtime Permissions for a ColdFusion page, hold down the Control key and click the name of the Runtime Permissions. ColdFusion pages in the directory cannot use Runtime Permissions that are listed in the Disabled Runtime Permissions box.
Please note: By default, all Runtime Permissions are enabled. However, you can choose to enable or disable the permissions listed in the Enabled Runtime Permissions box.
